Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Mined Semantic Analysis Commercialization Research
Award.AbstractNarration:
This I-Corps Teams project will help evaluate the commercial feasibility of improving knowledge work with Mined Semantic Analysis (MSA) software. A recent report on Artificial Intelligence, estimated a $2 trillion impact on knowledge work from machine automation/augmentation. As a solution that offers highly usable access to relevant domain knowledge, thereby enabling this economic shift, MSA potentially addresses millions of users. Applications include 1) Innovation management (technical document search) 2) Biomedical research (literature search) and 3) Business management (market/competitive research. MSA's concept based approach improves user interface visual prioritization, rapid comprehension and facile navigation to refine search. The software enables practical application of knowledge from billions of hours of human effort, thereby reducing the gap between novice and expert users.

The project aims to validate product market fit of MSA software through customer exploration and MVP prototype development. Building on work done over the past several months, the goal of the interviews is to identify specific market problems that the technology is capable of solving in a demonstrably better way. The I-Corps team will test high potential areas such as: Intellectual property research and analytics, Legal discovery, Investment/Consulting, Enterprise search, Knowledge management, Biomedical literature and Healthcare information search. The team's other project goal is to prototype core functionality to align with key customer performance measures. This will include quick experiments to gauge modes of user interaction and experience, visualization, and some preliminary performance testing.

Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: UNIVERSITY OF NORTH CAROLINA AT CHARLOTTE, THE

Performance_Institution.Name: University of North Carolina at Charlotte

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project investigated the commercial potential for a semantic search/information retrieval technology (called "mined semantic analysis" or MSA) by: (a) looking into the market potential for semantic patent search; (b) assessing the technical match between the MSA and the market needs. The project was part of the NSF I-Corps program.

Intellectual Merit: Commercial patent search products use only limited semantic information (for example, synonyms of words of the queries). Therefore MSA, by being able to find deeper semantic relationships based on conceptual relationships, was viewed as a potentially disruptive technology in the patent search. This was confirmed in our discussions with lawyers, IP licensing companies, patent miners and others.

Outcomes: (1) The project created a data set based on the decisions of the USPTO Patent Trial and Appeal Board (PTAB). Each data point corresponds to one decision and consists of a topic patent and 4-6 other patents forming the basis for the decision. This data was extracted using a combination of text mining and optical character recognition techniques, and was manually checked for quality. The data is publicly available. (2) The PTAB data set has been used to (i) test the accuracy of the MSA semantic search; (ii) develop the next iteration of semantic patent search yielding a four- fold improvement in accuracy of retrieval; (iii) will be the basis for testing an interactive version of the patent search, which is under development now. (3) The project team determined that the current –improved -- accuracy of our semantic search technology is not high enough for a software-based disruption of the commercial patent search; (4) Therefore, the team is currently pursuing the original vision of addressing the patent search market via a combination of software and consulting, and is expecting startup funding. (5) Several research publications have been published or are under review; a patent application is currently under review by the USPTO.

Other Impacts: Five students got involved in research, data mining and papers writing, as a result of this project. The PI incorporated some of the insights and techniques of the I-corps program into his classes and faculty discussions; this in turn sparked interest in the I-corps program among some students and faculty, resulting in two successful applications to the I-corps program.  

 

 


Last Modified: 09/02/2017
Modified by: Wlodek Zadrozny
